awd_titl_txt: BBSRC-NSF/BIO:Collaborative Research: Phage host range evolution in spatially structured microbiomes
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteriophages, the viral parasites of bacteria, are major agents of bacterial death in microbial communities or microbiomes. Previous work has shown that phage host range, the type of bacteria a given phage can successfully infect, can evolve rapidly. This evolution alters the impact that phage have on the composition and function of microbial communities. However, this previous work has focused on bacteria growing in well-mixed conditions while many bacteria in microbiomes exist in aggregations known as biofilms. In biofilms not only is the spatial arrangement of bacteria different, but also their physiology or lifestyle. In this project, which is a collaboration between researchers at the University of Minnesota (US), Dartmouth College (US) and the University of Exeter (UK), research will pair state of the art computer simulations with cutting edge experimental approaches to develop and test theory for predicting the impact that bacteriophage have on bacterial communities. This work will improve our ability to manage microbial communities that are vital for human health, agricultural production, and industrial applications. The project will help train the next generation of scientific leaders by working with postdoctoral researchers and graduate students to carry out the research. Additionally, it will develop teaching modules to engage high school students with the power of computational biology, preparing them to drive the bio-economy of the future.

Despite the abundance of phage and the prevalence of biofilm growth, little is known about the interaction between phage and biofilms. Specifically, there has been a paucity of investigation on how biofilms influence the evolution of phage host range. In addition to developing knowledge on a process that is critical to understanding microbiome behavior, the proposed work will also improve understanding of the evolution of generalist and specialist strategies more broadly. It will connect individual parasite movement to the dynamics of infection waves in heterogeneous environments. Additionally, it will quantify how host heterogeneity that arises from biotic and abiotic factors alters the evolution of parasite host range. The work will integrate a variety of models that span different length scales, with a powerful model system involving Escherichia coli and the bacteriophage T7. The research will develop and test theory to understand the impact of spatial organization, including the abundance of different hosts in a structured environment, the size of patches of hosts and the connectivity of these patches. The research will also develop and test theory to understand the consequences of bacterial matrix production, metabolic heterogeneity of hosts, and host mixing in biofilms. This collaborative US/UK project is supported by the US National Science Foundation and the UK Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Microbes inhabit the broadest spectrum of habitats that are known to permit life on Earth, ranging from the digestive tracts of aniaml hosts to the the most extreme abiotic environments in terms of heat, salinity, cold, and pH. In all of thes environments, bacteria for groups of cells on surfaces, called biofilms, which provide similar benefits as other forms of group living that are more familiar among multicellular organisms - increased access to limited resources, and protection from exogenous threats. Among the most common of these threats for bacteria are viruses, or phages, that attack and eitehr kill host bacteria or become temporarily dormant in by integrating their genome into the host's genomic DNA or plasmid pool. Despite the ubiquity of biofilm growth and of phages in the bacterial world, studies of phage propagation through biofilms that consider cellular-scale processes are still in their infancy. 

A primary focus of our research lab is to understand how phages interact (or don't interact) with their hosts within biofilm environments, and this grant in particular allowed us to develop new projects studying the impact of phage host range and propagation life history. Interestingly, we found that the advantage of being able to infect multiple hosts, which often comes at the cost of reduced infection speed, can be easily offset in the biofilm context, where slower infection speeds can be advantageous to present the exhaustion of the bacterial host supply for phage replication. We also completed work demonstrating that temperate phage mobilization not only direclty mediates horizontal gene transfer via movement of the phage genome, but it can also promote natural transformation due to the release of genomic bacterial DNA from lysed host cells. This DNA then becomes available for bacterial uptake and so promotes horizontal gene transfer veen more broadly. Finally, this award also allowed us to recruit new graduate students, who have begun development of projects on multispecies biofilm growth and its impact on the evolution of phage host range and phage life history strategy. Some phages - known as virulent or obligate lytic phages - can only undergo the lytic cycle in which their hosts are killed to produce more phages. Other phage types, including the temperate phages, are capable of the lytic cycle, but they can also integrate their genome into that of the host or replicate separately as a plasmid in the host cell. In this state, called lysogeny, phages replicate passively along with their bacterial host cells as they grow and divide. Our new projects are beginning to shed light on why some phages are lytic, while others are temperate, particularly in the context of biofilm growth. Our most recently completed project showed that temperate phages, for example, are excellent at becoming established in biofilm populations, because lysogenied hosts are generated mostly on the biofilm periphery and are prone to disperse to form new biofilms on their own. This is a unique strength of temperate phages' ability to lysogenize host bacteria and poitsn to new insights into the evolutionary stability of the temperate phage life history strategy used by many natural phages. 

The experimental and analytical methods developed for our projects have become widely used in the microbiology and biofilm literature, directly illustrating the impact of our methods development on the professional science community. Our work ahs also sparked new directions overall for phage biology research, which overlapped previously with biofilm research, but not using methods that allow for cellular scale imaging and quantitative analyses. This award also contributed to our lab's ability to recruit and train several new graduate students, including two from underrepresented communities in STEM. Finally, this award also supported ongoing outreach activities among the PIs, including to the local science education communities in the areas surrounding the supported institutions.
